title: Laser scan timestamp does not make sense

content.raw:
Here is a sequence of laser scan timestamps from VRC running on the SoftLayer machines:

~~~

header-timestamp  simulation-time-at-receipt  wall-time-at-receipt

  145.2350  145.2450   29.2710

  145.2350  145.2730   29.3160

  145.2680  145.3070   29.3710

  145.3010  145.3410   29.4260

  145.3330  145.3450   29.4320

  145.3440  145.3730   29.4800

  145.3750  145.4060   29.5340

  145.4060  145.4380   29.5890

  145.4370  145.4440   29.5990

  145.4370  145.4710   29.6450

  145.4690  145.5050   29.7030

  145.5090  145.5370   29.7580

  145.5390  145.5450   29.7720

  145.5390  145.5700   29.8160

  145.5690  145.6080   29.8810

  145.6090  145.6380   29.9330

  145.6390  145.6440   29.9430

  145.6390  145.6700   29.9890

  145.6690  145.7030   30.0470

  145.7090  145.7370   30.1060

~~~

Note that we start with duplicate header timestamps received at different times.
This occurs again at 145.4370, 145.5390, and 145.6390.

The scans with timestamps 145.2350 are different. I did not check the others.

The user guide says the header time stamp is when the scan started. If this were true, the header timestamps should be regular with gaps for missed samples.
This is clearly not the case in this plot of the difference between adjacent header timestamps.
[http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~cga/drc/laser-times1.png]()

The difference between the receipt time (in sim_time units) and the header time stamp should be at least the scan time (25ms). It is not.
[http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~cga/drc/laser-times2.png]()

Is this a problem with the GPU implementation?
Are the scans getting time stamped after a variable delay in GPU processing?
content.html:
Here is a sequence of laser scan timestamps from VRC running on the SoftLayer machines:

header-timestamp  simulation-time-at-receipt  wall-time-at-receipt

  145.2350  145.2450   29.2710

  145.2350  145.2730   29.3160

  145.2680  145.3070   29.3710

  145.3010  145.3410   29.4260

  145.3330  145.3450   29.4320

  145.3440  145.3730   29.4800

  145.3750  145.4060   29.5340

  145.4060  145.4380   29.5890

  145.4370  145.4440   29.5990

  145.4370  145.4710   29.6450

  145.4690  145.5050   29.7030

  145.5090  145.5370   29.7580

  145.5390  145.5450   29.7720

  145.5390  145.5700   29.8160

  145.5690  145.6080   29.8810

  145.6090  145.6380   29.9330

  145.6390  145.6440   29.9430

  145.6390  145.6700   29.9890

  145.6690  145.7030   30.0470

  145.7090  145.7370   30.1060

Note that we start with duplicate header timestamps received at different times. This occurs again at 145.4370, 145.5390, and 145.6390.

The scans with timestamps 145.2350 are different. I did not check the others.

The user guide says the header time stamp is when the scan started. If this were true, the header timestamps should be regular with gaps for missed samples. This is clearly not the case in this plot of the difference between adjacent header timestamps. http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~cga/drc/laser-times1.png

The difference between the receipt time (in sim_time units) and the header time stamp should be at least the scan time (25ms). It is not. http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~cga/drc/laser-times2.png

Is this a problem with the GPU implementation? Are the scans getting time stamped after a variable delay in GPU processing?
